options.b: Displays the location of the 'ls' command.

options.c: Disk space usage in human-readable format.

options.a: All running processes with full details.
options.b: All running processes for the current user.

options.a: Threats are internal, while vulnerabilities are external.
options.b: Threats are potential negative events, while vulnerabilities are weaknesses that could be exploited.
options.c: Threats are only associated with software defects, while vulnerabilities relate to hardware issues.
options.d: Threats are physical risks, while vulnerabilities are virtual risks.

options.a: To emphasize documentation over working software
options.b: To improve communication among development teams
options.c: To ensure each development phase has a corresponding testing phase
options.d: To encourage frequent changes to requirements

options.d: Conducting security testing on the code

questions.question:
What will be the output of the following code when executed with command-line arguments ./a.out "hello world"?

int main(int argc, char *argv[]) {
    printf("%c\n", argv[1][2]);
    return 0;
}

Which type of firewall operates at the application layer of the OSI model and can inspect data packets up to the application layer?
What is the purpose of the TTL (Time-to-Live) field in an IP packet header?

options.a: To specify the maximum data payload size.
options.b: To indicate the source of the packet.
options.c: To define the network route for the packet.
options.d: To limit the lifetime of the packet in the network.

What will be the output of the following code?


int main() {
    int *ptr = (int *)malloc(10 * sizeof(int));
    printf("%lu", sizeof(ptr));
    free(ptr);
    return 0;
}

questions.question:
What will be the output of the following code?
class Test {
public:
    int x;
    Test(int val) : x(val) {}
    int getValue() const {
        return x;
    }
    int getValue() {
        return x + 10;
    }
};

int main() {
    const Test obj1(10);
    Test obj2(20);
    std::cout << obj1.getValue() << std::endl;
    std::cout << obj2.getValue() << std::endl;
    return 0;
}

Given the following code, what will be the output?


class Test {
public:
    static int x;
    int y;
    Test() {
        y = ++x;
    }
    void print() {
        std::cout << "x: " << x << ", y: " << y << std::endl;
    }
};

int Test::x = 0;

int main() {
    Test t1, t2, t3;
    t1.print();
    t2.print();
    t3.print();
    return 0;
}

What will be the output of the following code?


class Test {
    int x;
public:
    Test(int x) {
        this->x = x;
    }
    Test& increase() {
        this->x += 10;
        return *this;
    }
    void print() const {
        std::cout << x << std::endl;
    }
};

int main() {
    Test obj(10);
    obj.increase().increase();
    obj.print();
    return 0;
}
Which of the following is not a type of constructor in C++?

What will be the output of the following code?


class Test {
    int x;
public:
    Test(int val) : x(val) {}
    bool operator!() const {
        return x == 0;
    }
};

int main() {
    Test obj1(0), obj2(10);
    if (!obj1) {
        std::cout << "obj1 is zero" << std::endl;
    } else {
        std::cout << "obj1 is not zero" << std::endl;
    }
    if (!obj2) {
        std::cout << "obj2 is zero" << std::endl;
    } else {
        std::cout << "obj2 is not zero" << std::endl;
    }
    return 0;
}

options.a:
obj1 is zero
obj2 is zero
options.b:
obj1 is not zero
obj2 is not zero
options.c:
obj1 is zero
obj2 is not zero

questions.question:
What will be the output of the following code?

using namespace std;

class Shape {
public:
    virtual void draw() {
        cout << "Drawing Shape" << endl;
    }
};

class Circle : public Shape {
public:
    void draw() override {
        cout << "Drawing Circle" << endl;
    }
};

int main() {
    Shape* shapePtr = new Circle;
    shapePtr->draw();
    delete shapePtr;
    return 0;
}

What will be the output of the following code?


class Test {
    int x;
public:
    Test() {
        x = 0;
    }
    Test(int val) {
        x = val;
    }
    Test(double val) {
        x = static_cast(val);
    }
    void print() const {
        std::cout << x << std::endl;
    }
};

int main() {
    Test obj1, obj2(10), obj3(10.5);
    obj1.print();
    obj2.print();
    obj3.print();
    return 0;
}

What will be the output of the following code?

using namespace std;

class A {
public:
    virtual void display() {
        cout << "A ";
    }
};

class B : public A {
public:
    void display() override {
        cout << "B ";
    }
};

int main() {
    A* ptr = new B;
    ptr->display();
    delete ptr;
    return 0;
}

What will be the output of the following code?


int main() {
    int x = 5, y = 6;
    if (++x > 5 || --y > 5) {
        printf("%d %d", x, y);
    } else {
        printf("%d %d", y, x);
    }
    return 0;
}

What will be the output of the following code?

using namespace std;

class A {
public:
    virtual void show() {
        cout << "A" << endl;
    }
};

class B : public A {
public:
    void show() override {
        cout << "B" << endl;
    }
};

int main() {
    A* a = new B();
    a->show();
    delete a;
    return 0;
}
Which of the following are correct about arrays in C?

options.a: Arrays can store elements of different data types.
options.b: Arrays are stored in contiguous memory locations.
options.c: The first element of an array has index 0.
options.d: The size of an array must be specified at compile time.

questions.question: Which of the following are valid function declarations in C?
Which of the following are true about constructors in C++?

options.a: A constructor has the same name as the class.
options.b: Constructors do not have a return type.
options.c: There can be multiple constructors in a class.

questions.question: Which of the following are true about polymorphism in C++?

options.a: Function overloading is a type of polymorphism.
options.b: Operator overloading is a type of polymorphism.

questions.question: Which of the following are properties of a binary search tree (BST)?

options.a: The left subtree contains only nodes with keys less than the node’s key.
options.b: The right subtree contains only nodes with keys greater than the node’s key.
options.c: Each node has at most two children.

questions.question: Which of the following are true about a doubly linked list?

options.a: Each node contains a pointer to the next node.
options.b: Each node contains a pointer to the previous node.
options.c: It allows traversal in both forward and backward directions.
options.d: It consumes less memory than a singly linked list.

questions.question: Which of the following are features of the Unix operating system?
Which of the following are correct about file permissions in Unix?

options.a: Permissions are divided into read, write, and execute.
options.b: Permissions can be set for the owner, group, and others.
options.c: The chmod command is used to change file permissions.
options.d: The chown command is used to change file permissions.

questions.question: Which of the following are types of CPU hazards in pipelining?
Which of the following are true about cache memory?

options.a: It is a small, fast memory located close to the CPU.
options.b: It reduces the average time to access data from the main memory.
options.c: It uses techniques like write-through and write-back for data consistency.
options.d: It is slower than main memory but faster than secondary storage.

questions.question: Which of the following are scheduling algorithms used by operating systems?
Which of the following are true about deadlock in operating systems?

options.a: Deadlock occurs when a set of processes are unable to proceed because each is waiting for resources held by the others.
options.b: The four necessary conditions for deadlock are mutual exclusion, hold and wait, no preemption, and circular wait.
options.c: Deadlock prevention, avoidance, detection, and recovery are strategies to handle deadlock.
options.d: Deadlocks can be completely eliminated in all operating systems.
